data.text:
BHPian

Join Date: Sep 2010

Location: Bengaluru

Posts: 199

Thanked: 3,176 Times

re: The Bangalore Metro rail (BMRCL) thread!

Now that the missing link is open, everybody wakes up to the fact that there are not enough trains to mitigate the crushing crowd, and to BMRCL's very poor planning .

Quote:

To maintain a healthy frequency of three to four minutes, experts say, BMRCL should have one train per kilometre. In Phase 1, BMRCL had 50 trains for 45 km, but there are only 57 trains now, even though the total network length has increased to 73 km.

In the last 5-6 years since phase 1 was completed, there has been an addition of just 7 trains!!

Quote:

When will the new coaches arrive?

In December 2019, the China Railway Rolling Stock Corporation (CRRC) Nanjing Puzhen Co. Ltd. was awarded the contract to supply 216 coaches, with an expected delivery to BMRCL within 173 weeks. Out of the 216 coaches, 126 (21 six-coach trains) will be deployed on the Purple and Green lines, while the remaining 90 coaches (15 six-coach trains) are designated for the under-construction Yellow Line (RV Road-Bommasandra). However, not one train set has reached Bengaluru so far.

Quote:

The first two metro trains from CRRC are expected to be shipped from China on October 18 and should arrive in Bengaluru within a month.

Quote:

Following this, Titagarh plans to deliver 12 cars each month to fulfil the order within the timeline of March 2025. BMRCL intends to deploy these trains on the Yellow Line initially and subsequently induct them into the Purple and Green Lines.

Source: Moneycontrol

So the only hope is that the Yellow line gets delayed a lot and these new trains (2 per month) are deployed by BMRCL for the purple or green lines.

ps - My estimate for Yellow line being operational is at least 9-10 months away i.e June-July 24.

Distinguished - BHPian

Join Date: Jun 2012

Location: BengaLuru

Posts: 5,745

Thanked: 19,763 Times

re: The Bangalore Metro rail (BMRCL) thread!

Quote:

Originally Posted by DigitalOne

So the only hope is that the Yellow line gets delayed a lot and these new trains (2 per month) are deployed by BMRCL for the purple or green lines.

That will mostly not happen due to the signalling systems on these rakes being different. And between the yellow line and purple/green lines there is no possibility of rake exchange.

Absolute lack of foresight and planning. The yellow line and green line run parallel at RV Road station and yet there was no thought about enabling a loop line between the two. The only possibility of rake exchange I see is via Yellow line to Blue line at silk board, and then blue line to purple at BYPL yard and so on.

On the other hand, I woke up late and ended up taking metro to office. It was pretty decent considering my start time was late and commute by car would have taken 1:30hr.

Started from my house in Banashankari at 8:45AM.

Reached National College Metro including parking at 8:55AM.

Thanks to five minute frequency of Green line, boarded train at 8:57AM

Switched to Purple line also running at 5min frequency at 9:03AM

Deboarded purple line at Kundanahalli(SAP Labs) 9:45AM

Immediately got a BMTC normal bus below the station and it dropped me bang in front of our tech park Brigade Tech Gardens at 9:55AM.

It was very seamless and no pain points anywhere. Purple line was under crush load between Majestic to MG road after which it got pretty good and I also managed to get a seat after MG road.

So I have decided to take metro when there will be heavy traffic and if I dont manage to start early to office. Otherwise its car for me.

Last edited by audioholic : 16th October 2023 at 11:33.

re: The Bangalore Metro rail (BMRCL) thread!

I wish I had enough detail of what actually happened in deciding which line to prioritize, and which line was more feasible to implement (in totality) first. Both at a local level and from the view of the central/GoI body that finances these projects across the country.

Having said that, traffic and commute will become easier once we have both the upcoming lines completed - the Yellow line for commuters on Hosur Road side, and the lines along ORR and the Bellary Road/Airport road line. If we cant wait, then can do what ever else one wants to do

Senior - BHPian

Join Date: Sep 2009

Location: Bangalore

Posts: 1,819

Thanked: 4,171 Times

re: The Bangalore Metro rail (BMRCL) thread!

I have been working in Bangalore for 18-19 years now and have never used public transport as my primary form of commute to work. However, im now fortunate to have a metro station right at my apartment society entrance ( Garudcharpalaya, Purple line).

And the start of the full fledged operation on the purple line coincided with my office shifting to Dairy Circle! So i tried this option, in the morning took the metro from Garudcharpalaya to MG road station, and thereafter opted for an auto rickshaw from the MG metro to my office. Total commute time 45 minutes. In the evening i was told that commuting from my office to MG is difficult, so i took an auto to the Jayanagar metro station and then rode the Green line to Majestic, shifted to purple line at the Majestic to go all the way back to Garudcharpalaya. This whole journey from my office entrance took about 1 hour and 15 minutes.

If i look at the overall commute time, im guessing me travelling by car would almost be the same owing to my office location being in a different area where there is no metro connectivity. However i find the metro way of commute time to be a bit more reliable, unlike the unpredictable traffic situations one may face on the road. But its not easy though, the metro is very crowded during the evening.

Lets see how it goes, i have no work from home option in my field of work, so going to office everyday is a routine. Will keep trying the metro option as much as possible.

Senior - BHPian

re: The Bangalore Metro rail (BMRCL) thread!

As of late, we are witnessing very rude behaviour by staff at Metro stations. The first incident happened on October 16th at Jayanagar Metro station. The staff at the counter were reluctant to issue daily passes and kept on moving us between counters until I started shouting. The station in charge rushed to the scene, warned the staff, and helped us get the pass. Today another incident happened at Chikpete, where a female security staff member behaved very rudely for asking about missing sign boards for toilets inside the station. Since I travel frequently by metro, it is very common to see the staff behaving rudely with passengers.

BHPian

Join Date: Jan 2023

Location: Bangalore

Posts: 113

Thanked: 216 Times

re: The Bangalore Metro rail (BMRCL) thread!

Quote:

Originally Posted by deehunk

As of late, we are witnessing very rude behaviour by staff at Metro stations. The first incident happened on October 16th at Jayanagar Metro station. The staff at the counter were reluctant to issue daily passes and kept on moving us between counters until I started shouting. The station in charge rushed to the scene, warned the staff, and helped us get the pass. Today another incident happened at Chikpete, where a female security staff member behaved very rudely for asking about missing sign boards for toilets inside the station. Since I travel frequently by metro, it is very common to see the staff behaving rudely with passengers.

I travel pretty frequently on the greenline between Doddakallsandra and Dasarahalli, what I noticed off late is there is a mixture of Private and Government staff at the stations. Right from security where I believe home guards were introduced in place of private security folks. Maybe this has got in the sarkari babu attitude of this is all you get, take it or leave it.

The other aspect could maybe be lacklustre incentives provided, it has been sometime since the considerable strech of metro has opened and maybe the employees are losing the initial enthusiasm they were having and are expecting more from the employer.

Distinguished - BHPian

Join Date: May 2010

Location: Bangalore

Posts: 1,962

Thanked: 12,652 Times

re: The Bangalore Metro rail (BMRCL) thread!

Quote:

Originally Posted by deehunk

As of late, we are witnessing very rude behaviour by staff at Metro stations.

So far, the security staff haven't really had too much to do. The Bangalore Metro is only now going to start seeing some sort of crowds. When you don't have too much work, you tend to do things that are not required and throw your authority around unnecessarily. Like analyze each and every thing in peoples' bags on the security scanner, like they have time to do now at some under-used stations! That will all quickly come to an end once the crowds start using the metro, they are going to have their hands full and will be forced to become efficient.

Quote:

Originally Posted by deehunk

The attitude of staff at ticket counters has to be rectified;...but in practice, they have made their own rules of what to do and what not to do.Most of the crowd never really questions this...

Yes, they tend to do that. By all means we have to complain. Ask for the complaint book (they will never tell you about it) and record the complaint. Enough people do that, things will change. The staff at the Indiranagar Metro station used to make up their own rules for when one of the entrances would be open or closed! Often there would be a jam at the main entrance, when another perfectly good entrance was shut, even in the afternoon! Many of us regular commuters started complaining and making a fuss about that. Now it works as required.

Last edited by am1m : 27th October 2023 at 10:06.

Distinguished - BHPian

Join Date: May 2010

Location: Bangalore

Posts: 1,962

Thanked: 12,652 Times

re: The Bangalore Metro rail (BMRCL) thread!

Happy to see the crowds on the Purple Line, towards Whitefield in the morning and back in the evening! Shows that if you build it, they will come. We can find excuses to not use public transport (and the Metro still has a long way to go), or find a way to make it work for us. Enough people seem to be making it work already. May it go from strength to strength! It has personally changed my life, making it possible to avoid a lot of Bangalore traffic and I'm so much happier and healthier because of that.
